meeting_annotations.speaker: Martin Gruebele
meeting_annotations.transcript: But even 2D is very helpful because then you can do tomography, right? meeting_annotations.speaker: Holly Goodson
meeting_annotations.transcript: I also really like the idea of trying to use evolution to perturb things, push them one way or another, both so that you could test ideas and then or or set it up so that your methods might be more applicable. meeting_annotations.speaker: Martin Gruebele
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's right. And and you know, plenty of lab techniques have been developed that can do this on minutes to hours, days kind of time scales. We don't have to wait eons.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Holly Goodson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Laura, I had a question for you. What is the limit these days on what can be done with imaging mass spec and what do you can you imagine getting down what what types of things would need to happen in order to improve on that?
meeting_annotations.other: Touches her forehead as she formulates the question, indicating deep thought.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Laura Sanchez
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, so I think commercial instruments in theory can do five microns. I think in practice, if you're at five microns, it's just really hard to get a signal. So like normally I think 10 to 20 is more common microns. And then I think, you know, there have been a lot of really nice technological advances. So like mass spectrometry is inherently inefficient at creating ions. So they've incorporated this like secondary lasers to make it more efficient. So I think the sensitivity and resolution is it's really it's advanced quite a bit in the last even five years. So it's just still like it's copy number limited, ionization efficiency, but they're working on making that more efficient.
meeting_annotations.other: Rests her chin on her hand, looking up and to the side as she recalls technical details.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Martin Gruebele
meeting_annotations.transcript: Have people actually combined expansion techniques with MS imaging? Because you know, if you could expand by a factor of a thousand volume or 10 in length, then suddenly you have one micron imaging reliably even though you're getting 10 micron.
meeting_annotations.other: Uses large, expansive hand gestures to illustrate the concept of expansion.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Laura Sanchez
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, not to my knowledge, but I that's why I feel like when it was when Lydia suggested it, I was like, that's smart because then that's a way around the technical limitation if it can be because yeah, we're thinking about multimodal imaging and incorporating different kinds of imaging to try to get at this like, you know, if you can fluorescently label proteins and then take look at the metabolites, but I think this is a that's also like just changing the scale is a really clever way.
meeting_annotations.other: Smiles and nods enthusiastically when referencing a colleague's idea.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Martin Gruebele
meeting_annotations.transcript: Let let the biology and the instrumentation meet in the middle somewhere, you know.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Martin Gruebele
meeting_annotations.transcript: This would by the way, I mean, it could very generally help a lot of techniques. It could certainly help fluorescence techniques also, right? meeting_annotations.other: Uses hand gestures to illustrate expansion and contraction.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Martin Gruebele
